s.text: Last fall, Morris gave an interview to the Door , the world's funniest evangelical humor magazine, in which he traced the arc of this sort of spiritual/professional recovery.
He is succeeding as a political pundit in part because of his interesting vantage point--he hates Hillary but loves Bill--and in part because he is the Michael Milken of the attention economy.

He is succeeding as a political pundit in part because of his interesting vantage point--he hates Hillary but loves Bill--and in part because he is the Michael Milken of the attention economy.
But he can't stop spinning ideas, images, and sound bites, can't stop playing everything to his advantage.
It shouldn't have been a complete surprise when I walked into the elevator in my Washington office building and came upon Dick Morris clutching a book by the late Cardinal Bernardin.
But he can't stop spinning ideas, images, and sound bites, can't stop playing everything to his advantage.
If you remember the issues floated by the Clinton re-election campaign--gun control for deadbeat dads, for example--the tone will be familiar.
If you remember the issues floated by the Clinton re-election campaign--gun control for deadbeat dads, for example--the tone will be familiar.
But it is the web of easy evasions that is the essence of Morrisism, both in his politico past and in his Augustinian present.

It takes religion, removes all the dark images that drive up its negatives--like judgment, obligation, or anything that might not be career enhancing--and replaces them with self-esteem and moral medals of honor.
Morris' real focus, as he lets you know before you have a chance to ask, is the Higher Realms.
